description:
Anoplophora glabripennis, commonly known as the Asian longhorned beetle (ALB), is a species of wood-boring beetle native to China and the Korean Peninsula. It is an invasive pest that has caused significant damage to hardwood trees in North America and Europe.

The Asian longhorned beetle is a large, black and white beetle, typically measuring between 20-35 millimeters in length. Its distinctive features include long antennae that are longer than its body, and square-shaped white spots on its black wing covers. The larvae of the ALB are whitish, legless grubs that burrow deep into the wood of host trees, which can ultimately lead to the tree's death.

The beetle primarily infests hardwood trees, such as maple, birch, poplar, and willow, and its presence can be identified by the presence of large, round exit holes in the trunk and branches of affected trees. The larvae feed on the inner bark and cambium, disrupting the tree's vascular system and causing it to weaken and eventually die.

Efforts to control and eradicate the Asian longhorned beetle involve the removal and destruction of infested trees, as well as the implementation of strict quarantine measures to prevent the further spread of the pest. Ongoing research is also being conducted to develop more effective methods of detection and management of this significant threat to forest ecosystems.
